We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's severe hyperglycemia and low serum sodium suggest hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS). The best initial step in management is to administer fluids to correct for dehydration and improve electrolyte balance. Lactated Ringer's solution is preferred over normal saline as it more closely matches the electrolyte composition of extracellular fluid. Regular insulin and potassium will also be given, but after fluid resuscitation. 3% hypertonic saline is not recommended as it has a risk of causing osmotic demyelination syndrome. Glargine insulin is not appropriate for the acute management of HHS.
